Cursor AI: 2-Week Journey and Rules of AI

I’ve officially switched from GitHub Copilot to Cursor AI.

Kenji

63

Two weeks into my journey with Cursor AI, I’ve fully transitioned from GitHub Copilot. The switch has significantly increased my productivity, mostly through multi-file editing and context-aware suggestions. This has reinforced my decision to subscribe to Cursor AI.

Let’s recap the key features that have made this transition so impactful:

While these features are impressive, I initially overlooked one more: “Rules for AI.” This feature has quickly become essential, enhancing the AI’s ability to match my coding style and project requirements.

What are “Rules for AI”?

“Rules for AI” allows you to set custom instructions that guide Cursor AI’s behavior when generating code or providing suggestions. It’s like having a system prompt to ensure your code aligns with your standards and best practices.

Benefits of “Rules for AI”

It’s worth noting that it takes time to fine-tune your rules and understand how they impact the AI’s suggestions. Additionally, overly restrictive rules might limit the AI’s creativity in problem-solving.

As I reflect on my journey from Copilot to Cursor, I’m struck by how rapidly the landscape of AI-assisted development is evolving. Other tools like Devin and Replit AI are pushing boundaries, which is good for us consumers. It is an exciting time, and I’m sure there will be more AI tools coming out. However, for now, I am sticking with Cursor AI.
